Award.AwardTitle: UTeach Dallas Robert Noyce Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
For the Nation to maintain its leadership in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and respond to the growing diversity and needs of its school population, it is important to increase the production of STEM teachers who are well prepared to teach in high-need schools. This project, an extension of an existing Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program on the University of Texas at Dallas campus, is designed to meet that challenge. The Title I independent school districts of Dallas, Carrollton-Farmers Branch, Garland, and Richardson are partners in this project. UTeach Dallas features a compact set of professional development courses that enable a STEM major to complete the required science and mathematics education courses, student-teaching experiences, and the requirements for a STEM major in four years. The program emphasizes engaging students early and often in STEM teaching experiences. Each year the project will offer an average of ten internships to support freshman and sophomore STEM majors as they explore teaching as a profession through proffered courses and mentored teaching opportunities. Additionally, eight Noyce Scholarships will be offered - six to STEM undergraduates and two to STEM degree holders, who want to return to the university in order to become STEM teachers. The Phase II UTeach Dallas Noyce Scholarship project anticipates adding up to forty new STEM teachers to the teaching workforce over the five years of its operation.

UTeach Dallas partners closely with high-need school districts and student populations while working under the umbrella of the School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics. Promising freshman and sophomore STEM majors are recruited into, and supported through, two early practicum courses in which they work with mentor teachers in local high-needs schools. Students then make a commitment to continue as Noyce Scholars with the courses and requirements needed to earn their STEM degree. Scholars also take a set of professional development courses and mentored high school teaching experiences to prepare for teaching certification. The extension of the UTeach Dallas Noyce Scholarship program into Phase II will enable enhanced project evaluation and research activities, along with strengthening identity and community among UTeach Dallas Noyce Scholars. University of Texas at Dallas faculty will also investigate and implement strategies to increase retention of UTeach Dallas students in their STEM majors. Noyce scholars are provided three years of induction and professional development opportunities once they begin teaching in local schools. Tracking of graduates will be done both internally and in partnership with the UTeach Institute which has a number of validated instruments developed for this specific purpose. The project will produce additional STEM teachers while simultaneously enabling more meaningful longitudinal studies of early Noyce graduates now teaching.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UTeach Dallas Noyce Teacher Scholarship program at the University of Texas at Dallas (UT Dallas) provided scholarship support to 40 STEM majors and degree holders to complete their secondary teaching certification with seven students receiving multiple years of support. UTeach Dallas Noyce Scholars were publicly honored and provided with special opportunities for conference attendance, professional development, and networking.  Professional development programs for in-service teachers, including UTeach Dallas Induction, partnered with the UTeach Dallas Noyce Teacher Scholarship program to enrich opportunities available to Noyce Scholars.

 

This grant provided support for internships to a total of 39 STEM majors for participation in numerous activities such as staffing and leadership of the UT Dallas Women in Physics summer camps for middle and high school students, staffing and support for other STEM camps, opportunities for peer mentoring, and assistance to faculty and staff with UTeach Dallas and STEM courses for undergraduates, in-service teacher professional development, and outreach. With the exception summer of 2020 due to COVID-19, the Women in Physics camps served, at no cost to participants, between 40 and 70 middle and high school girls each summer of the grant with the goal of encouraging participants to develop and maintain positive attitudes towards physics and STEM careers.

 

Over the lifetime of this Phase II Noyce program 179 students UTeach Dallas students have earned secondary STEM teacher certification. Recruiting of STEM majors to give teaching a try reached its highest levels, with 190 students taking the introductory one-credit hour teaching course Step 1 in the 2019?2020 academic year. The UTeach model, by design, recruits STEM majors who may have never considered teaching as a career before coming to the university. Although many of those who are given the opportunity to teach lessons to students in public schools during the introductory courses do not choose teaching as a career, each nonetheless learns valuable communication and collaboration skills while serving as role models to elementary and middle school students.

 

Research supported by this grant resulted in successful recruiting strategies including posters with targeted, positive messages about teaching placed prominently in School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics teaching facilities, a recruiting video, and approval from the university to allow a version of the Step 1 course to count towards the freshman seminar requirement. UTeach Dallas implemented a STEM Education minor to increase the attractiveness of seeking a teacher certification and retooled its upper level research and mathematical modeling courses to better serve students seeking mathematics certification. This grant supported the creation, implementation, and preliminary analysis of the Academic Attitudes of Undergraduates survey to investigate the academic mindset of the freshmen with the School of Natural Sciences and Mathematics and the creation and deployment of a summer 2020 survey of UTeach Dallas graduates on supports needed during the challenges of COVID-19.

 

The primary goal of the UTeach Dallas Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program has been to continue and increase the success of UTeach Dallas in recruiting, preparing, and supporting STEM majors to become successful secondary STEM teachers in high needs schools. UTeach Dallas continues to have a 100% placement rate for graduates seeking a teaching position. Retention in the teaching profession is high, with 87% of UTeach Dallas teachers still teaching since our first graduating class in 2011. Within the first five years of teaching retention of our graduates in the profession is 93%. UTeach Dallas graduates are estimated to impact 150 secondary students each year they teach. This year alone, the 184 UTeach Dallas graduates who are currently teaching will impact over 27,000 students. UTeach Dallas continues to place a high priority on placing our students in high needs schools serving economically disadvantaged and underserved/underrepresented populations. This year, over 90% of placements for clinical teaching have been in high needs schools and 68% of the UTeach Dallas graduates who are teaching have chosen to take their first job in high-needs schools despite a high demand from affluent area school districts.

 

A project for enhancing a multivariable calculus course at the UT Dallas, led by Co-PI and Professor of Mathematical Sciences, Dr. John Zweck, was made possible through a supplement to this grant. UTeach Dallas students served as undergraduate teaching assistants to support the implementation of small group active learning using white boards. Funds were provided by the university to continue the active learning activities past those provided by the supplement. A collection of 3D printed models representing multivariable calculus equations were also created for the project. The purpose of the models is to assist students with development of their 3D visualization skills by allowing them to view, hold, and rotate these physical mathematical representations. Files for other universities to create their own physical copies of the 3D models are freely available on the project website.
